Award.AwardTitle: Volunteerism among private-land owners for detection of invasive species

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Management of our nation's natural resources to meet important social goals will rely increasingly on volunteerism among private-landowners. This research explores the use of citizen volunteers to collect data for use by an agency that monitors for invasive pests of oak woodlands. Increasing group identity and a sense of community among the woodlot owners, enhancing trust in government agencies, and providing feedback on their volunteering efforts may increase the likelihood that these private landowners will initially volunteer and then continue their monitoring for the first appearance of several high priority invasive insect pests.

The research studies two social interventions to increase volunteerism: one aimed to increase levels of common in-group community identity, and the other aimed to increase trust in the governmental agency that regulates invasive species in Minnesota. The team will learn whether increased levels of community identity increase volunteer participation, and if increased trust in a specific governmental agency further increases participation above the effect of increased community identity. The research also will evaluate factors related to the retention of volunteers, contrasting the effect of prompt, extensive feedback versus minimal feedback on the quality and quantity of volunteer work, and on the long term retention rate.

The broader impact of this research goes beyond the invasive species problems in question and extends to general issues involving volunteerism, collective identity, trust in government, and the efficiency of joint government-citizen-volunteer efforts. The focus is on understanding what motivates citizens to get involved in local governance and decision making.

Practical goals are to reduce the cost and improve the effectiveness of detecting invasive species, and to meet public demands for conservation services from private landowners. Presently, the cost of agency-based monitoring and inadequate detection is high. Specific information about the effectiveness of proposed interventions to increase civic engagement and trust in government has great social value for reducing these costs. The findings also have the potential to improve management of invasive species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volunteerism among private-land owners for detection of invasive species

Invasive species are those not naturally occurring in a region and if established would cause significant harm. Invasive species of oak (Fig. 1) are the largest invasive species threat to the US and would add substantially to the costs of invasive species if they would establish or spread throughout the US. For example, prevention of establishment of oak splendor beetle (from Europe) and oak ambrosia beetle (from east Asia) would probably save more than $300 million per year in timber losses alone. Delaying the spread and damage of gypsy moth (Fig. 2), which occurs throughout eastern US but not throughout the Midwest, could save more than $200 million annually. Prevention and delaying spread require early detection monitoring, which is costly. Increased volunteerism by individual private-land owners is expected to reduce the costs and improve the accuracy of monitoring.  

We conducted an experiment to increase the rate of volunteerism by private woodland owners to look for invasive oak species on their land by heightening their identification with each other as woodland owners. We contacted all woodland owners in central Minnesota with more than five acres of oak woodlands. Most were contacted by mail to heighten their woodland owner identity by meeting with them and explaining the threat of invasive species to their land and the benefits of early detection for their region. A smaller proportion was reserved as a cold-contact control group, who just received an invitation by mail to volunteer. We predicted that by heightening their identity as woodland owners, the volunteerism rate would be higher, the level of engagement in the program would be greater, and the rate of retention from one year to the next would be higher than for those who only received a mail invitation. We prepared a monitoring guidebook for volunteers to have as a reference and reminder of the significance of their volunteer activities (Fig. 3), and held training sessions to improve the level of comfort and create a sense of community in their efforts (Fig. 4). Volunteers were asked to participate for 15 weeks during the summer, to hang four insect traps in their woodlands (Fig. 5), and to mail to us weekly the insects collected from the traps and their assessments of insect damage on five of their trees.

Woodland owners who experienced our efforts to heighten their awareness were no more likely to volunteer (5.1%, n = 1138) than those who merely received an invitation by mail to volunteer (7.2%, n = 223) and the rate of retention in subsequent years was not different (heightened identity 62.9%, n = 70, and mail invitation 60.0%, n = 20). The level of engagement was measured by the number of weeks during the summer that a volunteer contributed and the number of activities completed each week. Engagement was higher for volunteers who experienced our efforts to heighten their awareness; they contributed 3.1 more weeks and 0.7 more activities each week. 

The main non-monetary benefits volunteers said they obtained from participation in the project included benefits to society and benefits to the individual (Fig. 6). We used economic methods to estimate the monetary value of these benefits based on “willingness to accept” money to leave the project, and their “willingness to be pay” to join the project. On average, the willingness to accept value was greater than $1000.  The benefits most closely related to this were the individual benefits “creating a closer connection with the University of Minnesota” and “feeling more connected with my woodlands”. The social benefits were not a significantly associated with this value.
